member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Xml.GetValue
member.summary: Allows an XPath query to be executed on a set of specified XML documents. Returns the selected values as a semicolon delimted string. If a single MatchValue is provided, each XPath query is matched against the same value. If a list of MatchValues are provided, the value in the list is matched against the Xml document with the corresponding index. If a MatchValue list is provided with more than one item, the list must have the same number of items as there are in the Path parameter.

remarks.para: where:
The path to the Xml document to apply the XPath query against.
The XPath query to be executed against the given Xml document.
Stores the results of the query as a semicolon delimited string.

The value to match against the XPath query result(s). If one item is provided, the query for all specified Xml documents are matched against this single value. If a list of items is provided, the list must first have the same number of items as are in the Path parameter. The respective value in the list is then used when matching against query results.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Web.WebSite.CreateVirtualDirectory
member.summary: Create a new virtual directory
member.remarks:
<Web.WebSite.CreateVirtualDriectory VirtualDirectoryName="virtualDirectoryName" Path="path" MachineName="machineName" AppPoolID="appPoolID" AppCreate="appCreate" WebSiteName="webSiteName" AnonymousUserName="anonymousUserName" AnonymousUserPassword="anonymousUserPassword" UncUserName="uncUserName" UncPassword="uncPassword" AuthFlags="authenticationFlags" AccessFlags="accessFlags" />
where:
virtualDirectoryName (Required)
name of the virtual driectory to create
path (Required)
Path to map the virtual directory to.
machineName
Machine to add the virtual directory on.
appPoolID
Application pool to run the virtual directory under (IIS6 only).
appCreate
Set to "true" to create an application for this virtual directory.
webSiteName
Web site to attach the virtual directory onto.
anonymousUserName
Account to run anonymous users under.
anonymousUserPassword
Password for the anonymous users account.
uncUserName
Account to connect to a UNC share under when the Path property is a UNC path.
uncPassword
Password for the connection to a UNC share.
authFlags
Authentication flags to apply to the directory.
accessFlags
Access flags to apply to the directory. ///

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Web.WebSite.CreateVirtualDirectory VirtualDirectoryName="vdirName" Path="c:\temp" MachineName="remotemachine" AppPoolID="IIS6AppPool" AppCreate="1|0" WebSiteName="MySite" AnonymousUserName="anonaccount" AnonymousUserPassword="anonpassword" UncUserName="domain\user" UncPassword="uncpassword" AuthFlags="authenticationFlags" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.Update
member.summary: Updates a versionnumber.exe.config file to the correct number
member.remarks:
Note. This checks out the file in question from Source Control, updates the number and then checks the updated file back in. It only works with Source Depot currently.
<VersionNumber.Update VersionNumberConfigFileLocation="versionNumberConfigFileLocation" OnlyIncrementRevision="onlyIncrementRevision" <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" ItemName="versionNumberItem"></Output> </VersionNumber.Update>
where:
versionNumberConfigFileLocation (Required)
Fully qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="major" value="1" /> <add key="minor" value="2" /> <add key="build" value="1354" /> <add key="revision" value="155" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
onlyIncremementRevision
Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.

member.summary: If TRUE doesn't checkout or submit to source control

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.Update.OnlyIncrementRevision
member.summary: If TRUE only the revision part of the build number will be incremented
member.value: Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.Update.VersionNumberFormat
member.summary: If specified then this values indicates how the build number is calculated. i.e. a format of yyMMdd on July 15th ,2004 would give 040715. Note, this must only contain valid date formatting characters. If not specified the the build number format is the number of days since startDate from the xmlFile. If startDate is not specified then it defaults to Jan 1st, 2000.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.CreateSourceFiles
member.summary: Creates the VersionNumber.cs and VersionNumber.h files from the config file provided. Typically these files are then linked in to each of your projects If you provide BuildNumber and RevisionNumber then your provided values are used and not the values from the config file
member.remarks:
<VersionNumber.CreateSourceFiles OutputPath="outputPath" ConfigFileLocation="configFileLocation" Filename="filename" BuildNumber="buildNumber" RevisionNumber="revisionNumber" </VersionNumber.CreateSourceFiles>
where:
outputPath
The path to the folder where VersionNumber.cs and VersionNumber.h will be written.
filename
The filename to use as the root for the generated files. Defaults to VersionNumber
configFileLocation
Fully qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
buildNumber
If you set this value then the value from the config file is ignored.
revisionNumber
If you set this value then the value from the config file is ignored.
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="language" value="C++;C#" /> <add key="major" value="2" /> <add key="minor" value="0" /> <add key="build" value="050304" /> <add key="revision" value="001" /> </appSettings> </configuration>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Ping
member.summary: Pings a computer with a buffer of data to ensure it is visible and the data does not get corrupted.

remarks.code: <Ping Machine="machine" Count="count" Interval="interval" Timeout="timeout" BufferSize="bufferSize" AllowFragmentation="allowFragmentation" TimeToLive="timeToLive" LogSuccess="logSuccess"/>
remarks.para: where:
The name or IP address of the machine to ping.
The number of ping requests to send. The default is four.
The interval in milliseconds between ping requests. The default is no interval.
The maximum time in milliseconds to wait for a response. The default is five seconds.
The size of the data buffer to send in bytes, which must be between 1 and 65,500 bytes inclusive. Note that unless fragmentation is allowed then large buffers may fail. The default size is 32 bytes.
Whether the packet is allowed to be fragmented. The default is false.
The time-to-live for the packet, that is the number of times it can be forwarded by gateways and routers before the packet is deemed undeliverable and discarded. The default is 128.
Indicates whether to log successful pings to the console. The default is false.
The number of ping requests that failed.
The average round trip time for the ping requests.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Ping Machine="mymachine" Count="2" Interval="1000" Timeout="3000" BufferSize="1024" AllowFragmentation="false" TimeToLive="128" StopOnSuccess="true" LogSuccess="true"> <Output TaskParameter="FailureCount" PropertyName="FailedPingCount" /> <Output TaskParameter="RoundTripTime" PropertyName="RoundTripDuration" /> </Ping> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Ping.InternalExecute
member.summary: Executes the task.

member.summary: Gets the average round trip time in milliseconds for all successful pings. If no pings were successful then this returns zero.
member.value: The average round trip time in milliseconds.

member.value: The maximum time in milliseconds to wait for a response.

member.value: The maximum number of times the packet can be forwarded.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Create
member.summary: Creates a share on either the local or a remote machine.

remarks.code: <Share.Create ShareName="shareName" Path="path" Type="type" Description="description" AllowedUsers="allowedUsers" DeniedUsers="deniedUsers" MaximumAllowed="maximumAllowed" Machine="machine" UserName="userName" Password="password" />
remarks.para: where:
The name of the share to create.
The full physical path to create the share at.
The type of share to create. This can be one of the following values: DiskDrive, PrintQueue, Device, Ipc, DiskDriveAdmin, PrintQueueAdmin, DeviceAdmin, IpcAdmin. The default is DiskDrive.
A description of the share that users can see when they connect to it.

A delimited list of the users or security groups who are allowed to access the share, in the format DOMAIN\Username. If none are supplied and nobody is in the deniedUsers then everybody is given full access to the share. If none are supplied there are accounts in deniedUsers then nobody is given access to the share.

A delimited list of the users or security groups who are explicitly denied to access the share, in the format DOMAIN\Username. If none are supplied then nobody is explicitly denied access to the share.
The maximum number of users who are allowed to simultaneously connect to the share. Use zero for no limit. The default is no limit.
The name or IP address of the machine to create the share on. The default is the local machine.

If different credentials are needed to connect to a remote machine, this is the user name in the form DOMAIN\Username. This must not be supplied for the local machine. The default is to use the same credentials as the user the task is running as.
The password for the user account specified by userName. The default is no password.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Share.Create ShareName="Software" Path="C:\Software\" Type="DiskDrive" Description="Software library" AllowedUsers="domain\username;domain\domain admins;MyMachine\Administrator" DeniedUsers="domain\guests;MyMachine\Guest" MaximumAllowed="10" Machine="MyMachine" UserName="domain\username" Password="password1" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Create.BuildAccessControlEntry(System.Management.ManagementScope,System.Management.ManagementObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Builds a Win32_ACE for a trustee.
member.remarks: To simplify this class and the inputs, this ACE just uses full permissions for the trustee, so an "allow" ACE will grant all permissions and a "deny" ACE will deny all permissions. This should be fine as this is only access to the share, and the actual access to the files will be controlled by the computer's file system permissions which we don;t change.
member.param: The to create the trustee in.
The Win32_Trustee to create the ACE for.
If true then this is a deny ACE, else it is an allow one.
member.returns: A Win32_ACE .

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Exists
member.summary: Checks whether a share exists on either the local or a remote machine.

remarks.para: where:
The name of the share to check for.
The name or IP address of the machine to check for the share on. The default is the local machine.

If different credentials are needed to connect to a remote machine, this is the user name in the form DOMAIN\Username. This must not be supplied for the local machine. The default is to use the same credentials as the user the task is running as.
The password for the user account specified by userName. The default is no password.
true if the share does exist, or false otherwise.

member.example:
The following example shows how this task may be used with the Share.Delete task to conditionally delete a share.
<Project> <PropertyGroup> <SoftwareShareExists /> </PropertyGroup> <Target Name="Test"> <Share.Exists ShareName="Software" Machine="MyMachine" UserName="domain\username" Password="password1"> <Output TaskParameter="DoesExist" PropertyName="SoftwareShareExists" /> </Share.Exists> <Share.Delete Condition="'$(SoftwareShareExists)'=='true'" ShareName="Software" Machine="MyMachine" UserName="domain\username" Password="password1" /> </Target> </Project>

member.summary: Executes the task

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Exists.DoesExist
member.summary: Gets whether the share does exist.
member.value: true if the share does exist, or false otherwise.

The VSS database location. This database must exist and must be a valid VSS database.

The password for the username specified in username
The SourceSafe version to use. Default is 6d. Supports 6d and 2005

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <SourceSafe.Changes Database="database" Username="username" Password="password" PathDiff="hum.c"> <Output TaskParameter="ChangesFound" PropertyName="Found" /> </SourceSafe.Changes> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CheckProductInstalled
member.summary: Check that a particular product is installed, such as Microsoft Visual Studio .NET

remarks.code: <CheckProductInstalled Names="names" Versions="versions" NameComparisonOperators="nameComparisonOperators" VersionComparisonOperators="versionComparisonOperators" UnaryOperators="unaryOperators" InstalledProductsXml="installedProductsXml"> <Output TaskParameter="Summary" ItemName="SummaryItem" /> <Output TaskParameter="Success" ItemName="SuccessItem" /> </CheckProductInstalled>
remarks.para: where:
Names of the products to be checked for, for example, "Microsoft Visual Studio .NET"
The versions of products to be checked for. Wildcard can be specified as an asterisk. Version must be numeric and separated by either "." or ","
Name comparison operators for each of the product names speciifed in names. Can be any of: "Equals", "Contains" "LessThan" "GreaterThan" "LessThanOrEquals" "GreaterThanOrEquals"
Name comparison operators for each of the product versions speciifed in versions. Can be any of: "Equals", "Contains" "LessThan" "GreaterThan" "LessThanOrEquals" "GreaterThanOrEquals"
Unary operators for the respective nameComparisonOperators, allowing (for example) "Not Equals" to be created. Can be "None" or "Not".
A list of the products installed on the local machine. This will typically be generated by the task

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <CheckProductInstalled Names="NDoc" Versions="1.2.0" NameComparisonOperators="Equals" VersionComparisonOperators="Equals" UnaryOperators="None" InstalledProductsXml="@(InstalledProductsXmlItem)"> <Output TaskParameter="Summary" ItemName="SummaryItem" /> <Output TaskParameter="Success" ItemName="SuccessItem" /> </CheckProductInstalled> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Web.FtpSite.Create
member.summary: Create a new FTP site.

remarks.code: <Web.FtpSite.Create Description="description" Path="path" IPAddress="ipAddress" Port="port" AccessFlags="accessflags" AllowAnonymous="allowAnonymous" AnonymousUsername="anonymousUsername" AnonymousPassword="anonymousPassword" Identifier="identifier" HostName="hostName" />
remarks.para: where:
A description for the FTP site to be created.
Local path to assign as the FTP root.

IP address to listen on. This can be any valid IPV4 address. If this IP address is not bound to a local NIC the FTP server will not start. If this property is not set, the FTP site will listen on all available addresses on the hosting machine.
Port for the FTP site to listen on.
Set to true to allow access to anonymous users
Account to run anonymous users under
Password for the anonymous users account
Access flags for the FTP site (either "AccessRead", "AccessWrite", or both combined)
Any non-existant FTP site identifier.
Host header to bind to (only valid for non-SSL sites).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.SourceSafe.GetVSSFiles
member.summary: Performs a Get from the Visual SourceSafe specified.
member.remarks:
<SourceSafe.GetVSSFiles Database="database" Username="username" Password="password" GetParameter="getParameter" Label="label" OnlyIncremementRevision="onlyIncrementRevision" Project="project" VersionNumber="versionNumber" VersionNumberConfigFileLocation="versionNumberConfigFileLocation" VersionNumberConfigVSSLocation="versionNumberConfigVSSLocation" WorkingDirectory="workingDirectory" > SSVersion="ssversion"> </SourceSafe.GetVSSFiles>
where:
database
The VSS database location. This database must exist and must be a valid VSS database.
username
The username that will be used when labelling VSS
password
The password for the username specified in username
getParameter
Allows a specific version of files/projects to be supplied
label
Label to use when getting a particular version.
onlyIncremementRevision
Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.
project
The VSS style syntax for project location.
versionNumber
If specified then $(VersionNumber) is set to this value and replaced as appropriate in the xml config file
versionNumberConfigFileLocation
Fully Qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
ssversion
The SourceSafe version to use. Default is 6d. Supports 6d and 2005
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="major" value="1" /> <add key="minor" value="2" /> <add key="build" value="1354" /> <add key="revision" value="155" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
versionNumberConfigVSSLocation
The path to the config file specified in versionNumberConfigFileLocation inside VSS, using VSS-style notation.
workingDirectory
The full path to the working directory on the local machine for the cod

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <SourceSafe.GetVSSFiles Database="database" GetParameter="getParameter" Label="label" OnlyIncremementRevision="onlyIncrementRevision" Project="project" VersionNumber="versionNumber" VersionNumberConfigFileLocation="versionNumberConfigFileLocation" VersionNumberConfigVSSLocation="versionNumberConfigVSSLocation" WorkingDirectory="workingDirectory" > </SourceSafe.GetVSSFiles> </Target> </Project>

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.Password
member.summary: Sets the password used by the server process to log on under the identity. Password should be set at the same time as Identity, because the password and identity are validated before being saved. If the password and identity get out of sync, the application cannot be launched until they are reset by an administrator.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.Identity
member.summary: Sets the server process identity for the application. Specify a valid user account or "Interactive User" to have the application assume the identity of the current logged-on user. This is not enabled for library applications, which run in the client process. The Password property should be set at the same time as Identity, because the password and identity are validated before being saved. If the password and identity get out of sync, the application cannot be launched until they are reset by an administrator.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.Name
member.summary: The name of the application. Extra spaces at the beginning and end of the string are stripped out. Unique names should be chosen for applications. If multiple applications are created with the same name, it can interfere with referencing the applications by name, resulting in unpredictable behavior.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.ApplicationId
member.summary: A GUID representing the application. ApplicationID is ReadWrite whilst creating a new Application and readonly afterwards.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.AccessChecksEnabled
member.summary: Indicates whether access checks are performed for the application when clients make calls into it.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.Activation
member.summary: Local activation indicates that objects within the application run within a dedicated local server process (server application). In-process activation indicates that objects run in their creator's process (library application). Defaults to local.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.ShutdownAfter
member.summary: Sets the delay before shutting down a server process after it becomes idle. Shutdown latency ranges from 0 to 1440 minutes (24 hours). If RunForever is set to True, this property is ignored. ShutdownAfter is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.ComponentServices.Application.RunForever
member.summary: Enables a server process to continue if an application is idle. If set to True, the server process does not shut down when left idle. If set to False, the process shuts down according to the value set by the ShutdownAfter property. RunForever is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ActiveDirectory.Group.AddUser
member.summary: Adds an Active Directory User to either a domain group or a local group.

remarks.code: <ActiveDirectory.Group.AddUser UserName="userName" GroupName="groupName" UserDomain="userDomain" GroupDomain="groupDomain" GroupMachine="groupMachine" EnsureUserIsInGroup="ensureUserIsInGroup" />
remarks.para: where:
The name of the user to add to the group.
The groupname to add the user to.
The domain the user belongs to. If not specified it defaults to the local machine.
The domain the group belongs to. Specify either this or GroupMachine. If neither are specified then a group on the local machine is assumed.
The machine the group belongs to. Specify either this or GroupDomain. If neither are specified then a group on the local machine is assumed.
If "true" and the User is already in the group then no error is thrown. If false, an error will be thrown if the specified user is already a member of the specified group. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <ActiveDirectory.Group.AddUser UserName="user1" GroupName="Domain Administrators" UserDomain="mydomain" GroupDomain="mydomain" EnsureUserIsInGroup="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ActiveDirectory.Group.AddUser.InternalExecute
member.summary: Performs the action of this task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ActiveDirectory.Group.AddUser.GroupMachine
member.summary: The machine the the group is on.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Xml.XslTransform
member.summary: Xsl an Xml file. This version is quite simplistic and doesn't support chaining or parameters.

remarks.code: <Xml.XslTransform XmlFile="xmlFile" Path="path" Output="output" XslFile="xslFile" ResultFile="resultFile" Extension="extension" </Xml.XslTransform>
remarks.para: where:
The full path and filename of the xml file to be transformed. This is only used in conjunction with the ResultFile property.
The full path and filename of the xsl file to be used in the transformation.
The path to a folder containing xml files that require transforming. This is only used in conjunction with the Output property.
The path to a folder where transformed files will be placed. This is only used in conjunction with the Path property.
The full path and filename of the result of the transformation. This file will be created if it does not exist. This is only used in conjunction with the XmlFile property.

The file extension to give to the transformed files. If unspecified the transformed files are automatically given an xml extension. This is only used in conjunction with the Path and Output properties.

example.code:
<Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Xml.XslTransform XmlFile="C:\SourceFiles\file1.xml" XslFile="C:\SourceFiles\Transform.xsl" ResultFile="C:\TransformedFiles\Output.htm" </Xml.XslTransform>
<Xml.XslTransform Path="C:\SourceFiles" XslFile="C:\SourceFiles\Transform.xsl" Output="C:\TransformedFiles" </Xml.XslTransform> </Target> </Project>

members.member: TODO: What this should do is allow Xml strings as input and xml strings as output but that would require more complexity as a "WriteToFile" task would be needed. It should also support parameters being passed into the XSL.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Web.WebSite.Create
member.summary: Create a new web site

remarks.code: <Web.WebSite.Create Description="description" Path="path" MachineName="machineName" AuthFlags="authFlags" AppPoolId="appPoolId" HostName="hostName" Identifier="identifier" IPAddress="ipAddress" Port="port" LogFileDir="logFileDir" DirBrowseFlags="dirBrowseFlags" DefaultDocs="defaultDocs" />
remarks.para: where:
Web site description to continue.
Local path to assign as the web root.
IP address the new site should listen on.
Port number to listen on.
Host header to bind to (only valid for non-SSL sites).
Web site identifier to continue.
Authentication flags to apply to the site.
Local path to assign as the folder that contains the log files.
Application pool to run the site within (IIS6 only).
Directory browsing flags to apply to the site.
Document names allowed as default document for the site.
Machine to operate on(defaults to localhost)

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Web.WebSite.Create Description='My New Site' Path='$(CurrentFolder)\Solution\Secure'/> </Target> <Target Name="TestWithDefaultDoc" > <Web.WebSite.Create Description='My New Site' Path='$(CurrentFolder)\Solution\Secure' DirBrowseFlags="EnableDefaultDoc" DefaultDocs="Default.aspx;Default.html;index.html;index.htm" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Tools.DevEnv
member.summary: Executes DevEnv.exe to build the .sln file specified.

remarks.para: where:
The version of Visual Studio to use. Specify 7.0, 7.1 or 8.0.
The path to the .sln file.
The solution configuration to build. Typically, Debug or Release.
If multiple platforms are possible, the name must also contain platform name.
for example: "Debug|Win32"
If specified, the folder to write the DevEnv output to.
True to pass the Clean command line argument to DevEnv.exe

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Tools.DevEnv VisualStudio="8.0" Path="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\..\Solutions\MainSolution\Main.sln" Config="Release" OutputFolder="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\Output\Main" Clean="true"> <Output TaskParameter="ExitCode" PropertyName="MyExitCode"></Output> </Tools.DevEnv> <Message Condition=" '$(MyExitCode) != '0' " Text="ExitCode was non-zero" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Sql.Execute
member.summary: Execute the SQL query or script against the specified server and database

remarks.para: where:
The server to grant access to.
The database on the specified server to grant access to.
If you do not specify a server and database name you must specify a connection string.
An OLE/DB connection string detailing the connection parameters required.
If you do not specify a connection string you must specify a serverName and databaseName
Maximum time allowed to perform the task (seconds)
SQL command line to execute
Full qualified or wildcard path to script(s) to execute
A list of files to exclude from execution if a wildcard path has been specified
A list of tokens to substitute when executing the specified SQL.
Flag indicating action to take on failed execution

example.code:
<Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Sql.DisconnectUsers UserName="testUser" ServerName="(local)" DatabaseName="testDB" CommandTimeout="60" /> </Target> </Project>
<Project DefaultTargets="Default" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/developer/msbuild/2003"> <Import Project="Microsoft.Sdc.Common.tasks"/> <ItemGroup> <myString Include="true"> <name>@P1</name> <value>'Hello'</value> </myString> <myInteger Include="true"> <name>@P2</name> <value>342</value> </myInteger> </ItemGroup> <Target Name="Default"> <Sql.Execute Path="SDCParameter.sql" ServerName="." DatabaseName="master" Parameters="@(myString);@(myInteger)"/> </Target> </Project>
Where SDCParameter.sql contains: DECLARE @Str1 NVARCHAR(100); DECLARE @Int1 INT;
SET @Str1 = @P1; SET @Int1 = @P2;
RAISERROR('Str1 is: %s', 0, 1, @Str1) WITH NOWAIT RAISERROR('Int1 is: %d', 0, 1, @Int1) WITH NOWAIT
-- Replaced Text DECLARE @Str1 NVARCHAR(100); DECLARE @Int1 INT;
SET @Str1 = 'Hello' SET @Int1 = 342
RAISERROR('Str1 is: %s', 0, 1, @Str1) WITH NOWAIT RAISERROR('Int1 is: %d', 0, 1, @Int1) WITH NOWAIT
-- Result Str1 is: Hello Int1 is: 342

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Disconnect
member.summary: Disconnects from a share.

remarks.para: where:

The name of the share to disconnect from. If the share is redirected to a local device name, e.g. E: or LPT1: then this argument should be the device name. If the share is not redirected then it should be the name of the share that was used.
If the share is redirected to a local device name, e.g. E: or LPT1: then this argument must not be specified. If the share is not redirected then it should be the name of the machine the share is on.
Either true or false. If true then the share will be disconnected even if it is in use. The default is false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <!-- Disconnect from a share redirected to a local device --> <Share.Disconnect ShareName="E:" Force="true" /> <!-- Disconnect from a share that is not redirected --> <Share.Disconnect ShareName="MyShare" Machine="MyMachine" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Sql.GetDatabaseVersion
member.summary:
Gets an extended property 'DatabaseVersionNumber' on the database specified in the connection string. This can be used in conjunction with 'SetDatabaseVersion' to control db initialization/upgrade scripts in installers etc.
This task deliberately returns 0.0 if there is no existing database at all 1.0 if the db exists but does not yet have the 'DatabaseVersionNumber' extended property

remarks.para: where:
The server hosting the database (ignored if a connection string is supplied)
The database (ignored if a connection string is supplied)
If you do not specify a server and database name you must specify a connection string.
An OLE/DB connection string detailing the connection parameters required.
If you do not specify a connection string you must specify a serverName and databaseName
Maximum time allowed to perform the task (seconds)

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Sql.GetDatabaseVersion ServerName="(local)" DatabaseName="testDB" CommandTimeout="60"> <Output TaskParameter="DatabaseVersion" PropertyName="DatabaseVersion"/> </Sql.GetDatabaseVersion> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.Parse
member.summary: Parses a version number from some text. Useful when the version number is generated by an external source.

remarks.code: <VersionNumber.Parse Text="text" VersionNamePath="versionNamePath"> <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" PropertyName="versionNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="VersionName" PropertyName="versionName" /> <Output TaskParameter="MajorNumber" PropertyName="majorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="MinorNumber" PropertyName="minorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="BuildNumber" PropertyName="buildNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="RevisionNumber" PropertyName="revisionNumber" /> </VersionNumber.Parse>
remarks.para: where:
The text containing the version number.
The path to the root folder for the current version.
The full version number containing the major, minor, build and revision numbers.
The name of the current version.
The major number for the version.
The minor number for the version.
The build number for the version.
The revision number for the version.

example.code:
<Project> <PropertyGroup> <Text>The version number is 1.2.0.6896 in this test.</Text> <VersionNamePath>$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\..\..</VersionNamePath> </PropertyGroup>
<Target Name="Test"> <VersionNumber.Parse Text="$(Text)" VersionNamePath="$(VersionNamePath)"> <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" PropertyName="VersionNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="VersionName" PropertyName="VersionName" /> <Output TaskParameter="MajorNumber" PropertyName="MajorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="MinorNumber" PropertyName="MinorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="BuildNumber" PropertyName="BuildNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="RevisionNumber" PropertyName="RevisionNumber" /> </VersionNumber.Parse>
<Message Text="Text: $(Text)" /> <Message Text="VersionNamePath: $(VersionNamePath)" />
<Message Text="VersionNumber: $(VersionNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="VersionName: $(VersionName)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="MajorNumber: $(MajorNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="MinorNumber: $(MinorNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="BuildNumber: $(BuildNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="RevisionNumber: $(RevisionNumber)" Importance="high" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Email
member.summary: Sends an email message

remarks.code: <Email MailTo="mailTo" MailFrom="mailFrom" SmtpServer="smtpServer" Subject="subject" Body="body" Format="format" Priority="priority" Attachments="attachments" />
remarks.para: The email address to send the email to.
The email address to send the email from.
The SMTP server to use to send the email.
The subject of the email.
The body of the email.
The text encoding format of the email. Defaults to "HTML".
The priority of the email. Defaults to "Normal".
A list of full paths of files to attach to the email.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Email MailTo="myDeveloper@myCompany.com;bob@myCompany.com" MailFrom="buildServer@myCompany.com" SmtpServer="mySmtpServer" Subject="Build succeeded" Body="Your changes have been successfully built." Format="HTML" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSateliteAssembliesFromResx
member.summary: Summary description for CreateSateliteAssembliesFromResx.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSateliteAssembliesFromResx.InternalExecute
member.summary:
This method will find all resx files from the source code root. It will generate a satelite assembly for each culture folder found and copy to a folder of the same culture name, creating if needed, in the deployAssemblyRootPath folder. The leaf folder name MUST be a valid .NET locale. (or 'CY')
1.For example - > a resx file in c:\sourceroot\en-gb\Microsoft.Sdc.Exceptions.DatabaseViolation.resx 2.Call method with c:\sourceroot as source path and c:\mainassemblies as deployAssemblyRoot and Microsoft.Sdc.Exceptions as assemblyRootName
3.An assembly is created marked with the en-gb locale at location c:\mainassemblies\en-gb called Microsoft.Sdc.Exceptions.resources.dll

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.DeleteElement
member.summary: Deletes any elements that match the specified XPath expression.

remarks.para: where:
The path of the XML file to modify.
The XPath expression to evaluate to find the element(s) to remove.
Optional TaskItems array detailing each of the namespace declarations required to read/maintain the target document. Each TaskItem should have 2 elements <Prefix> and <Uri>.
If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
If set to true, this will force the file to be updated even if it is Read Only. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <XmlFile.DeleteElement Path="c:\app.config" XPath="/configuration/appSettings/add" Namespaces="@(ConfigNamespaces)" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="true" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.PerformanceCounters.Add
member.summary: Add performance counters to the local machine

remarks.para: where:
The name of the custom performance counter category to create and register with the system. If a performance counter category with the specified name already exists, it will be deleted.
A description of the custom category.
An array of task items that specifies the counters to create as part of the new category.
Either true or false. If true then the performance counter will be a multiinstance counter. The default is false (single instance).

example.code:
<Project> <CustomCounterList Include="foobar.A" CounterName="Counter1" CounterHelp="First custom counter" CounterType="NumberOfItems32"/> <CustomCounterList Include="foobar.A" CounterName="Counter2" CounterHelp="Second custom counter" CounterType="NumberOfItems32"/> <CustomCounterList Include="foobar.A" CounterName="Counter3" CounterHelp="Third custom counter" CounterType="NumberOfItems32"/> <CustomCounterList Include="foobar.A" CounterName="Counter4" CounterHelp="Fourth custom counter" CounterType="NumberOfItems32"/> <CustomCounterList Include="foobar.A" CounterName="Counter5" CounterHelp="Last custom counter" CounterType="NumberOfItems32"/>
<Target Name="Test"> <PerformanceCounters.Add CategoryName="myCustomCategory" CategoryHelp="This is a custom performance counter category" CounterList="@(CustomCounterList)" MultiInstance="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.Repair
member.summary: Repairs an MSI package.

remarks.code: <Msi.Repair MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" RepairOptions="repairOptions" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to repair.
The GUID product code of the product to repair.
The path to the log file for the repair. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.repair.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom installation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of the options for repairing the MSI. The possible values are: Default, ReinstallWhenFileMissing, ReinstallWhenOlderVersionInstalled, ReinstallWhenEqualOrOlderVersionInstalled, ReinstallWhenDifferentVersionInstalled, ReinstallWhenChecksumIncorrect, ForceReinstall, RewriteUserSpecificRegistry, RewriteComputerSpecificRegistry, OverwriteExistingShortcuts, RunFromSourceAndReCachePackage. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for more information.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Folder.Share.Connect
member.summary: Connects to a share using the supplied credentials. You can use the task to disconnect from the share.

remarks.code: <Share.Connect ShareName="shareName" Machine="machine" UserName="userName" Password="password" LocalName="localName" ResourceType="resourceType" Connections="connections" />
remarks.para: where:
The name of the share to connect to.
The name or IP address of the machine the share is on.
The name of the user to connect to the share as, in the form DOMAIN\Username.
The password for the user account specified by userName. The default is no password.
The name of the local device to connect the share to, e.g. E: or LPT1:. This cannot be specified if the resourceType is "Any". The default is no local name.
The type of resource being connected to, which can be one of the following values: Any, Disk, Printer, Ipc.
The number of connections to make to the share.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Share.Connect ShareName="MyShare" Machine="MyMachine" UserName="domain\username" Password="password1" LocalName="E:" ResourceType="Disk" Connections="1" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.InstalledProducts.InstalledProductManager
member.summary: "Your WMI script uses the Win32_Product class, which the WMI Windows Installer Provider services. In XP and earlier, the WMI Windows Installer Provider is installed by default. Unfortunately, that's no longer the case beginning with Windows 2003. Instead, the WMI Windows Installer Provider is an optional component, as Figure 1, page 10, shows. To install this provider, open the Control Panel Add/Remove Programs applet and click Add/Remove Windows Components. Select the Management and Monitoring Tools check box, then click Details. Select the WMI Windows Installer Provider check box, and click OK."

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.EmbedUninstallProperties
member.summary: Uninstalls an MSI package.

remarks.code: <EmbedUninstallProperties MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to uninstall.
The GUID product code of the product to uninstall.
The path to the log file for the uninstallation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.uninstall.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom uninstallation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide uninstallation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of uninstallation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Msi.EmbedUninstallProperties MsiPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.msi" ProductCode="b6b6f41c-fd3e-4b5b-8a73-c59494974990" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.uninstall.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" > <Output TaskParameter="ExecArguments" PropertyName="ExecArguments" /> </Msi.EmbedUninstallProperties> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MergeByRef
member.summary:
Takes two item lists as input and merges them together based on a reference metadata. This is similar to merging two DB tables together based on a reference key to generate a view.
The output of this task is a copy of ItemList1 with additional metadata for the first item that matched in itemlist2. All of the metadata is copied over and the identity of the item in ItemList2 becomes ItemList2_Identity.
Note that if ItemList1 and ItemList2 have the same metadata names then the value from 2 will be kept (normally other than Identity this would not be expected input)
If RemoveNonMatchingItems is set to true then the result contains only items where a match occured. This defaults to false.

remarks.code: <MergeByRef ItemList1="@(list1)" MetaDataName1="Prop1" ItemList2="@(list2)" MetaDataName2="Prop2" RemoveNonMatchingItems="removeNonMatchingItems"> <Output TaskParameter="MergedList" ItemName="MergedList" /> </MergeByRef>
remarks.para: where:
The first ItemList to be merged
The second ItemList to be merged
The first ItemList's metadata
The second ItemList's metadata which maps to Prop1 metadata on the first Itemlist
The merged ItemList

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <MergeByRef ItemList1="@(AllAssemblies)" ItemList2="@(Solutions)"/> MetaDataName1="SolutionName" MetaDataName2="Identity" RemoveNonMatchingItems="true"/> <Output TaskParameter="MergedList" PropertyName="AssembliesFull" /> </ShortenPath> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MergeByRef.#ctor
member.summary: MergeByRef

member.summary: InternalExecute

member.summary: he first ItemList to be merged

member.summary: The second ItemList to be merged

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.AddElement
member.summary: Adds a new child element to any elements within the specified XML file that match the specified XPath expression. Optionally, it will also add a specified Key Attribute/Value pair to the new element so that subsequent tasks can identify the new element.

remarks.code: <XmlFile.AddElement Path="path" XPath="xpath" Name="name" Prefix="prefix" Value="value" KeyAttributeName="keyAttributeName" KeyAttributeValue="keyAttributeValue" Prepend="prepend" Namespaces="namespaces" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="ignoreNoMatchFalure" Force="force"/>
remarks.para: where:
The path of the XML file to modify.
The XPath expression to evaluate to find the parent element(s) to add the new element as a child.
The local name of the new element.
Optional value to give the new element.
Optional prefix for the namespace that this new element is to be a member of.
The name of the optional attribute to create in the new element to aid its location by subsequent tasks.
The value of the optional attribute to create in the new element to aid its location by subsequent tasks.
If true the new element is added to the beginning of the child elements of those elements matching the XPath expression. If false the new element is added to the end. Defaults to false.
Optional TaskItems array detailing each of the namespace declarations required to read/maintain the target document. Each TaskItem should have 2 elements <Prefix> and <Uri>.
If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
If set to true, this will force the file to be updated even if it is Read Only. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <XmlFile.AddElement Path="c:\app.config" XPath="/configuration/appSettings" Name="add" Prefix="" Value="element value" KeyAttributeName="key" KeyAttributeValue="instrumentationConfigFile" Prepend="true" Namespaces="@(ConfigNamespaces)" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="true" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.value: The optional attribute value to add to the new element.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Wix.CompileMsi
member.summary: Compiles an intermediate *.wixobj file for an MSI from Wix *.wxs input files. This intermediate file can then be used with the task to create a complete MSI package.

remarks.para: About Wix: Wix was originally a Microsoft tool that has been released into the open source community under the Common Public License. The binaries and source code can be downloaded from SourceForge.
where:
A delimited list of the source files to generate the intermediate file from. These will normally have the extension *.wxs. Please refer to the Wix documentation for the schema of these files.
The path to the intermediate object file to produce. This should have the extension *.wixobj.
The path to the directory that the Wix executables reside in.
An integer between zero (verbose information) and three (no information). The default is zero.
An integer between zero (all warnings) and three (no warnings). The default is zero.
true if warnings are treated as errors, or false otherwise. The default is false.
A delimited list of additional search paths for include files for the compiler.
A delimited list of compilation parameters for the compiler, with each parameter in the format Name=Value.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <CompileMsi SourceFiles="SourceFile1.wxs;SourceFile2.wxs" OutputFile="OutputFile.wxsobj" WixPath="C:\Program Files\Wix" InformationLevel="1" WarningLevel="2" TreatWarningsAsErrors="true" AdditionalSearchPaths="C:\Build\Msi\Includes;C:\Build\Msi\References" CompilationParameters="debug=false;ieversion=6.0;winver=5.1" /> </Target> </Project>

optional parameter to identify website when 'description' is not used
optional parameter to set max size of log files

ptional parameter to set the period of rollover to a new logfile(defaults to loaclhost)
optional parameter to set Bit mask of the attributes to log

member.summary: Modifies an existing Applcation Pool (IIS6 or later).

remarks.code: <Web.AppPool.Create AppPoolName="appPoolName" IdentityType="identityType" Identity="identity" Password="password" IdleTimeout="idletimeout" PeriodicRestartTime="periodicRestartTime" WorkerProcesses="workerProcesses" />
remarks.para: where:
Any existing IIS pool name
One of LocalSystem, LocalService, NetworkService, SpecifiedUserAccount

para.i: identity (Required if identitytype is set to "SpecifiedUserAccount")

remarks.para: Username to run the application pool as

remarks.para: Password for the application pool identity
The idle timeout (in minutes) for the application pool
The periodic restart time (in minutes) for the application pool
The number of worker processes for the application pool

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.VSSUpdate
member.summary: Updates a versionnumber.exe.config file to the correct number
member.remarks:
Note. This checks out the file in question from Source Control, updates the number and then checks the updated file back in. It only works with Source Depot currently.
<VersionNumber.Update ConfigFileLocation="configFileLocation" OnlyIncrementRevision="onlyIncrementRevision" <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" ItemName="versionNumberItem"></Output> </VersionNumber.Update>
where:
configFileLocation (Required)
Fully qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="major" value="1" /> <add key="minor" value="2" /> <add key="build" value="1354" /> <add key="revision" value="155" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
onlyIncremementRevision
Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.

member.summary: If TRUE doesn't checkout or submit to source control

member.summary: If TRUE uses VSS for source control

member.summary: If TRUE only the build part of the build number will be incremented
member.value: Force Build increment change. So 2.0.1188.0 would be 2.0.1189.0 on the next automatic label from the source control system.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.VSSUpdate.OnlyIncrementRevision
member.summary: If TRUE only the revision part of the build number will be incremented
member.value: Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.VSSUpdate.VersionNumberFormat
member.summary: If specified then this value indicates how the build number is calculated. i.e. a format of yyMMdd on July 15th ,2004 would give 040715. Note, this must only contain valid date formatting characters. If not specified the the build number format is the number of days since startDate from the xmlFile. If startDate is not specified then it defaults to Jan 1st, 2000.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.VSSUpdate.Database
member.summary: If specified then this value represents the VSS database location in VSS format e.g. V:\SourceSafe.

member.summary: If specified then this value represents the VSS username that has access to the database.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.VSSUpdate.Password
member.summary: If specified then this value represents the password for the VSS username specified.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Vault.GetLabel
member.summary: Performs a GETLABEL from the Sourcegear Vault server specified.

remarks.code: <Vault.GetLabel Server="server" Repository="repository" Username="username" Password="password" DestinationDirectory="destinationPath" ItemPath="itemPath" Label="label" VaultClientPath="clientExePath" UseSSL="useSSL" />
remarks.para: where:
The IP address or hostname of the Vault server to connect to.
The Vault username.
The password for the username specified in username
The full path to download repository files to.
The full repository path to the item to perform the get operation on.
The label version to get for item specified in itemPath
Optional - the path to vault.exe. If the Vault registry keys exist or the path to vault.exe is set in your enviroment path, this does not need to be used.
Optional (default False) - if set SSL will be used to communicate with the Vault server. If enabled the Vault server specified in server must support SSL.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Vault.GetLabel Server="192.168.1.100" Repository="MyCode" Username="username" Password="password" DestinationDirectory="c:\build_1000" ItemPath="$/Repos/Item" Label="build_1000" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Tools.FxCop
member.summary: Runs FxCop analysis on the assemblies specified, creates a summary file and returns the total number of violations.

remarks.para: where:
The fullpaths to the assemblies to analyze.
This will be the FxCop file that will be created from the template.
An .FxCop file to use as a template.
The name of the file to create with the FxCop summary in it.
The name of the item to create for MSBuild. It will be referred to as @(itemName).

example.code: <Project> <ItemGroup> <Assemblies Include="Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.Tasks.dll" /> <Assemblies Include="Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.Tasks.Test.dll" /> </ItemGroup> <Target Name="Test" > <Tools.FxCop ContinueOnError="true" Assemblies="@(Assemblies->'%(FullPath)')" ProjectFilePath="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\Output\Main\Main.FxCop" ProjectTemplateFilePath="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\FxCop\Main\main.FxCop" OutFileName="$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\Output\Main\FxCopErrors.xml"> <Output TaskParameter="TotalViolations" ItemName="FxCopViolations" /> </Tools.FxCop> <Message Text="@(FxCopViolations) FxCop violations" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.File.GetFiles
member.summary:
Allows an item list to be produced based upon searching a directory for matching file types. Multiple file types to search can be specified.
Multiple inclusions and exclusions can be specified, both of which can contain folders and explicit files.

remarks.code: <File.GetFiles Path="path" Masks="masks" Include="include" Exclude="exclude" Recursive="recursive" Group="group"> <Output TaskParameter="OutputFiles" ItemName="OutputFiles" /> </File.GetFiles>
remarks.para: where:
An item list of paths to use as the root for file searches.
An item list of files to include. This can be usefull for adding files that don't physically exist in the directory being searched.
An item list of folders and/or absolute files that should be excluded from the search.
Specifies if the search should include all sub-folders under the paths specified by the Path property. This defaults to true.
Specifies the value to apply to an attribute of the item list produced by the task. The attribute is called Group.
The item list resulting from the file search.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.InstallPatch
member.summary: Installs an MSI Patch. The patch will use properties that are already part of the current MSI that it is being patched, other properties can be passed during execution via the command line. In the case of property files only the properties that are marked //Property/@Embed='false' are passed via the command line as it is assumed that the embedded properties within the MSI are already there.

remarks.code: <Msi.InstallPatch MspPath="mspPath" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to install.
The path to the log file for the installation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.install.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom installation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide installation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of installation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.
A delimited list of the names of features to be installed. This is not necessary if the MSI does not have features configured, or you wish all features to be installed.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Msi.InstallPatch MspPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPatch.msp" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.install.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" Features="MSMQ,BTS2004,WebServices" /> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Wix.CompareFilesInFragments
member.summary: Compares 2 Wix fragment files and publishes file differences between them. Items of interest are that are detected are: files that are in one but not the other

remarks.para: Dynamically generated fragments are considered bad news when it comes to release installers as the component GUIDs keep changing and as such issues arise when making patches. This task can be used to compare a wix fragment that has been generated now with one generated early on and then baselined when the project is stable and release date is near.
About Wix: Wix was originally a Microsoft tool that has been released into the open source community under the Common Public License. The binaries and source code can be downloaded from SourceForge.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Web.WebSite.Modify
member.summary: Modifies an existing web site

remarks.code: <Web.WebSite.Modify Description="description" Path="path" AuthFlags="authFlags" AppPoolId="appPoolId" HttpExpires="httpExpires" DirBrowseFlags="dirBrowseFlags" DefaultDocs="defaultDocs" />
remarks.para: where:
Web site description to modify.
Local path to assign as the web root.
Authentication flags to apply to the site.
Application pool to run the site within (IIS6 only).
Content expiration in hours
Directory browsing flags to apply to the site.
Document names allowed as default document for the site.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Web.WebSite.Modify Description='My Site' Path='$(CurrentFolder)\Solution\Secure'/> </Target> <Target Name="TestWithDefaultDoc" > <Web.WebSite.Modify Description='My Site' Path='$(CurrentFolder)\Solution\Secure' DirBrowseFlags="EnableDefaultDoc" DefaultDocs="Default.aspx;Default.html;index.html;index.htm" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Tools.PsExec
member.summary: Executes PsExec.exe (available from www.sysinternals.com ) in order to execute a command on a remote machine.

remarks.code: <Tools.PsExec ToolPath="toolPath" WorkingDirectory="workingDirectory" Command="command" Server="server" User="user" Password="password" LoadProfile="loadProfile"> </Tools.Sn>
remarks.para: where:
The path to the folder where PsExec.exe can be found on the local machine.
The working directory the remote process should use.
The command to execute on the remote machine.
The remote machine on which the command should be executed.
The domain\user that should be used on the remote machine.
The password of the user that should be used on the remote machine.
If set to 'true' the profile of the user specified by user is loaded when executing the remote command.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Tools.PsExec ContinueOnError="true" ToolPath="c:\PsTools" Command="cmd /c mkdir c:\testdir" Server="MyRemoteMachine" User="MyAdminUser" Password="MyAdminPassword" </Tools.PsExec> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.Uninstall
member.summary: Uninstalls an MSI package.

remarks.code: <InstallMsi MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to uninstall.
The GUID product code of the product to uninstall.
The path to the log file for the uninstallation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.uninstall.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom uninstallation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide uninstallation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of uninstallation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <UninstallMsi MsiPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.msi" ProductCode="b6b6f41c-fd3e-4b5b-8a73-c59494974990" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.uninstall.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" /> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.File.RegEx
member.summary:
Reads in a text file and modifies the contents by searching for and replacing text satisfying a regular expression pattern.
The task File.Replace can also be used to fulfill this functionality and more. This version is kept for compatibility with previous versions.

remarks.para: where:
The full path and filename of the text file to be modified.
If set to true, this will modify the text file even if it is read-only. Set to false to ignore read-only files. Defaults to false.
The new value for the specified attribute.
The regular expression pattern to match.

example.code: <Project> <!-- Replaces runs of white space in file1.txt with a comma and a blank. --> <Target Name="Test" > <File.RegEx Path="C:\SourceFiles\file1.txt" RegularExpression="\s+" NewValue=", " /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update
member.summary: Updates the specified ComponentServices Application.

remarks.code: <ComponentServices.Application.Update ApplicationName="applicationName" Identity="identity" Password="password" ShutdownAfter="shutDownAfter" ActivationString="activationString" EnforceAccessChecks="enforceAccessChecks" RunForever="runForever" />
remarks.para: where:
The name of the COM+ application. This application will be created if it does not exist.

Sets the server process identity for the application. Specify a valid user account or "Interactive User" to have the application assume the identity of the current logged-on user. This is not enabled for library applications, which run in the client process.

Sets the password used by the server process to log on under the identity. Password should be set at the same time as Identity, because the password and identity are validated before being saved. If the password and identity get out of sync, the application cannot be launched until they are reset by an administrator.

Sets the delay before shutting down a server process after it becomes idle. Shutdown latency ranges from 0 to 1440 minutes (24 hours). If RunForever is set to True, this property is ignored. ShutdownAfter is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

Set to "Local" to indicate that objects within the application run within a dedicated local server process (server application). Set to "Inproc" to indicate that objects run in their creator's process (library application). Defaults to local
Indicates whether access checks are performed for the application when clients make calls into it.

Enables a server process to continue if an application is idle. If set to True, the server process does not shut down when left idle. If set to False, the process shuts down according to the value set by the ShutdownAfter property. RunForever is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <ComponentServices.Application.Update ApplicationName="MyApplicationName" Identity="Interactive User" ActivationString="Local" ShutdownAfter="60" RunForever="false" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.InternalExecute
member.summary: Performs the action of this task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.ApplicationName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the application to be updated.
member.value: The name of the COM+ application to be updated

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.Identity
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the user identity for the COM+ application
member.value: Sets the server process identity for the application. Specify a valid user account or "Interactive User" to have the application assume the identity of the current logged-on user. This is not enabled for library applications, which run in the client process.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the password of the user identity for the COM+ application.
member.value: Sets the password used by the server process to log on under the identity. Not required if the Identity property is set to "Interactive User".

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.ShutdownAfter
member.summary: Gets or sets the delay before shutting down a server process after it becomes idle.
member.value: The delay, in minutes, before the process shutsdown after becoming idle. Shutdown latency ranges from 0 to 1440 minutes (24 hours). If RunForever is set to True, this property is ignored. ShutdownAfter is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.ActivationString
member.summary: Gets or sets the type of activation for the application.
member.value: "Local" - local activation indicates that objects within the application run within a dedicated local server process (server application). "Inproc" - in-process activation indicates that objects run in their creator's process (library application). Defaults to "Local".

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.EnforceAccessChecks
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether access checks are performed for the application when clients make calls into it.
member.value: Set to true if access checks are to be performed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.Update.RunForever
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether a server process should continue if an application is idle.
member.value: If set to True, the server process does not shut down when left idle. If set to False, the process shuts down according to the value set by the ShutdownAfter property. RunForever is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CompileTestSummary
member.summary: This task compiles the test results xml file into a summary and produces an xml document.
member.remarks:
<CompileTestSummary Categories="categories" TestPass="testPass" TestFail="testFail" TestNoRun="testNoRun" TestTotal="testTotal" TestTimeTaken="testTimeTaken" OutputXmlFilename="outputXmlFilename" XsltFilename="xsltFilename" > <Output TaskParameter="TotalTestFailures" ItemName="TotalTestFailuresItem" /> </CompileTestSummary>
where:
categories (Required) List of the names of the test categories to be summarised.
testPass (Required)
List of the number of passed tests for each of the categories specified in categories. This will probably come from running the NUnit test .
testFail (Required)
List of the number of failed tests for each of the categories specified in categories. This will probably come from running the NUnit test .
testNoRun (Required)
List of the number of tests not run for each of the categories specified in categories. This will probably come from running the NUnit test .
testTotal (Required)
List of the total number of tests for each of the categories specified in categories. This will probably come from running the NUnit test .
testTimeTaken (Required)
List of the times taken for the tests for each of the categories specified in categories. This will probably come from running the NUnit test .
outputXmlFilename
The name of the xml filename to contain the test summary. Defaults to "testsummary.xml"
xsltFilename
The name of the Xsl stylesheet to use to transform the Xml summary into Html, if desrired.
outputHtmlFilename
The name of the file in which the transformed Xml summary is to be stored. Defaults to "Output\testsummary.html"

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <CompileTestSummary Categories="Category1; Category2; Category3; Category4" TestPass="2; 1; 1; 2" TestFail="0; 0; 0; 1" TestNoRun="1; 0; 0; 0" TestTotal="3; 1; 1; 2" TestTimeTaken="12; 10; 5; 9" OutputXmlFilename="C:\Output\Output.xml" XsltFilename="C:\Output\Output.xsl" OutputHtmlFilename="C:\Output\MyResults.htm"> <Output TaskParameter="TotalTestFailures" ItemName="TotalTestFailuresItem" /> </CompileTestSummary> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.EmbedInstallProperties
member.summary: Installs an MSI package.

remarks.code: <Msi.Install MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to install.
The GUID product code of the product to install.
The path to the log file for the installation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.install.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom installation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide installation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of installation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.
A delimited list of the names of features to be installed. This is not necessary if the MSI does not have features configured, or you wish all features to be installed.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Msi.EmbedInstallProperties MsiPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.msi" ProductCode="b6b6f41c-fd3e-4b5b-8a73-c59494974990" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.install.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" Features="MSMQ,BTS2004,WebServices" > <Output TaskParameter="ExecArguments" PropertyName="ExecArguments" /> </Msi.EmbedInstallProperties> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>
