member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Xml.ModifyFile
member.summary: Reads in an XML file and modifies the contents based on the XPath and values to replace in the file.

remarks.code: <Xml.ModifyFile Path="path" AttributeName="attributeName" Force="force" Namespace="namespace" NewValue="newValue" XPath="xPath" RegularExpression="regularExpression" > ShowMatches="showMatchOptionValue" > </Xml.ModifyFile>
remarks.para: where:
The full path and filename of the xml file to be modified.
The name of the xml attribute to be modified.
If set to true, this will modify the xml file even if it is read-only. Set to false to ignore read-only files. Defaults to false.
An array of TaskItems specifiying "Prefix" and "Uri" attributes for use with the specified xPath.
The new value for the specified attribute.
The XPath to the nodes containing the specified attribute. If the XPath expression includes a prefix, the prefix and namespace URI pair must be added to via the namespace property.
This property allows a regular expression to be provided in preference to an XPath.

Specifes whether XPath replacements are logged. Valid values are No, Yes, Masked, and Secure. If not specified then this options defaults to No. The Yes option displays the replacement text while the Masked and Secure options obscure the replacement text. These options are useful when the replacement text is sensitive data such as passwords. The Masked option replaces each character of the replacemen text with an asterisk character. The Secure option always displays 8 asterisks for the replacement text.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Xml.ModifyFile Path="C:\SourceFiles\file1.xml" XPath="/TestNodes/TestNode" AttributeName="NodeID" NewValue="MODIFIED" ShowMatches="Yes" </Xml.ModifyFile> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Web.Smtp.Create
member.summary: Create a new SMTP Server.

remarks.code: <Web.Smtp.Create Description="description" IPAddress="ipAddress" Port="port" AuthFlags="authflags" SmartHost="smartHost" MasqueradeDomain="masqueradeDomain" FullyQualifiedDomainName="fullyQualifiedDomainName" DefaultDomain="defaultDomain" PickupDirectory="pickupDirectory" DropDirectory="dropDirectory" QueueDirectory="queueDirectory" BadMailDirectory="badMailDirectory" Identifier="identifier" HostName="hostName" />
remarks.para: where:
A description for the SMTP site to be created.

IP address to listen on. This can be any valid IPV4 address. If this IP address is not bound to a local NIC the SMTP server will not start. If this property is not set, the SMTP site will listen on all available addresses on the hosting machine.
Port for the FTP site to listen on.
Authentication flags for the SMTP site (either "Anonymous", "Basic", "NTLM", or "Digest")
Any non-existant FTP site identifier.
Host header to bind to (only valid for non-SSL sites).
The smarthost to forward messages to.
The masquerade domain to use.
The FQDN to use.
The default domain to use.
The folder for the pickup directory.
The folder for the drop directory.
The folder for the queue directory.
The folder for the bad mail directory.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Web.Smtp.Create Description="TestSmtp" DropDirectory="c:\smtp\drop" PickupDirectory="c:\smtp\pickup" QueueDirectory="c:\smtp\queue" BadMailDirectory="c:\smtp\badmail" SmartHost="MySmartHost" DefaultDomain="MyDefaultDomain" AuthFlags="Anonymous" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.LoadFileVersion
member.summary: Loads the file version number from a file.

remarks.code: <VersionNumber.LoadFileVersion FileName="fileName" VersionNamePath="versionNamePath"> <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" PropertyName="versionNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="VersionName" PropertyName="versionName" /> <Output TaskParameter="MajorNumber" PropertyName="majorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="MinorNumber" PropertyName="minorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="BuildNumber" PropertyName="buildNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="RevisionNumber" PropertyName="revisionNumber" /> </VersionNumber.LoadFileVersion>
remarks.para: where:
The file containing the version number.
The path to the root folder for the current version.
The full version number containing the major, minor, build and revision numbers.
The name of the current version.
The major number for the version.
The minor number for the version.
The build number for the version.
The revision number for the version.

example.code:
<Project> <PropertyGroup> <FileName>$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\MyAssembly.dll</FileName> <VersionNamePath>$(MSBuildProjectDirectory)\..\..</VersionNamePath> </PropertyGroup>
<Target Name="Test"> <VersionNumber.LoadFileVersion FileName="$(FileName)" VersionNamePath="$(VersionNamePath)"> <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" PropertyName="VersionNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="VersionName" PropertyName="VersionName" /> <Output TaskParameter="MajorNumber" PropertyName="MajorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="MinorNumber" PropertyName="MinorNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="BuildNumber" PropertyName="BuildNumber" /> <Output TaskParameter="RevisionNumber" PropertyName="RevisionNumber" /> </VersionNumber.LoadFileVersion>
<Message Text="FileName: $(FileName)" /> <Message Text="VersionNamePath: $(VersionNamePath)" />
<Message Text="VersionNumber: $(VersionNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="VersionName: $(VersionName)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="MajorNumber: $(MajorNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="MinorNumber: $(MinorNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="BuildNumber: $(BuildNumber)" Importance="high" /> <Message Text="RevisionNumber: $(RevisionNumber)" Importance="high" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.VersionNumber.Load
member.summary: Loads the version number properties from the version number file specified.
member.remarks:
<VersionNumber.Load VersionNamePath="versionNamePath" ConfigFileLocation="configFileLocation" ConfigVSSLocation="configVSSLocation" <Output TaskParameter="RevisionNumber" ItemName="revisionNumberItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="MajorNumber" ItemName="majorNumberItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="MinorNumber" ItemName="minorNumberItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="BuildNumber" ItemName="buildNumberItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="StartDate" ItemName="startDateItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="VersionNumber" ItemName="versionNumberItem"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="VersionName" ItemName="versionNameItem"></Output> </VersionNumber.Load>
where:
versionNamePath
The path to the root folder for the current version.
configFileLocation
Fully qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="major" value="1" /> <add key="minor" value="2" /> <add key="build" value="1354" /> <add key="revision" value="155" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
configVSSLocation
The path to the config file specified in versionNumberConfigFileLocation inside VSS, using VSS-style notation.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Tools.SandcastleBuilder
member.summary: Calls SandcastleBuilder in order to generate compiled HTML documentation for the specified assemblies. SandcastleBuilder is an open-source tool that packages up Sandcastle toolset to operate in a similar manner to NDoc

remarks.code: <Tools.SandcastleBuilder Assemblies="assemblies" ProjectFilePath="projectFilePath" OutputPath="outputFilePath" SandcastlePath="sandcastlePath" PresentationStyle="presentationStyle" OutputPath="outputPath" HelpFileFormat ="helpFileFormat "> </Tools.SandcastleBuilder>
remarks.para: where:
The fullpaths to the assemblies to create docs for.
This will be the Sandcastle Help File Build Project file that will be used as a template.
The name of the folder to create all the compiled help docs in. The value in the project file will be used if not specified
Defines the presentation style for the help topic pages. Allowed values are Prototype/VS2005
The name of the folder to where the Sandcastle Toolset is installed. The value defined in the project file will be used if not specified

Available format are HtmlHelp1x HTML Help 1.x format built with HHC.EXE HtmlHelp2x HTML Help 2.x format built with HXCOMP.EXE Website A web site with basic frame set viewer page Help1xAndWebsite An HTML Help 1.x file and web site Help2xAndWebsite An HTML Help 2.x file and web site

member.summary: Labels the latest versions of files in a Visual SourceSafe project.

remarks.code: <SourceSafe.LabelLatest Database="database" Username="username" Password="password" Label="label" Project="project" SSVersion="ssversion"> </SourceSafe.LabelLatest>
remarks.para: where:
The VSS database location. This database must exist and must be a valid VSS database.
The username that will be used when labelling VSS
The password for the username specified in username
Label to apply to the latest versions of all files in the project.
The VSS style syntax for project location.
The SourceSafe version to use. Default is 6d. Supports 6d and 2005

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <SourceSafe.LabelLatest Database='\\build5\SourceSafe\Pilot\db' Project='$/Projects/Main/$(VersionName)' Username='myDomain\theBuilder' Password='123$abc' Label='Daily_050625' /> </SourceSafe.LabelLatest> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.DeleteAttribute
member.summary: Deletes the named attribute from all elements in the specified file that match the specified XPath expression. Will fail of no matches found for the XPath expression.

remarks.para: where:
The path of the XML file to modify.
The XPath expression to evaluate to find the parent element(s) to remove the attribute from.
The name of the attribute to delete.
Optional TaskItems array detailing each of the namespace declarations required to read/maintain the target document. Each TaskItem should have 2 elements <Prefix> and <Uri>.
If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
If set to true, this will force the file to be updated even if it is Read Only. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <XmlFile.DeleteAttribute Path="c:\app.config" XPath="/configuration/appSettings/add" Name="key" Namespaces="@(ConfigNamespaces)" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="true" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.value: The name of the new element to append to each element matching the XPath Expression.

member.summary: If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.ComponentServices.Application.AddComponent
member.summary: Adds a component to the specified ComponentServices Application.

remarks.code: <ComponentServices.Application.AddComponent Path="path" ApplicationName="applicationName" ComponentName="componentName" ConstructorString="constructorString" Identity="identity" Password="password" Runtime="runtime" ShutdownAfter="shutDownAfter" ActivationString="activationString" EnforceAccessChecks="enforceAccessChecks" RunForever="runForever" />
remarks.para: where:
The valid path to the DLL to be added to application.
The name of the COM+ application. This application will be created if it does not exist.

Sets the server process identity for the application. Specify a valid user account or "Interactive User" to have the application assume the identity of the current logged-on user. This is not enabled for library applications, which run in the client process.

Sets the password used by the server process to log on under the identity. Password should be set at the same time as Identity, because the password and identity are validated before being saved. If the password and identity get out of sync, the application cannot be launched until they are reset by an administrator.
Decimal value for version of runtime targeted. Mandatory for .NET components to be registered. Defaults to "2.0"

Sets the delay before shutting down a server process after it becomes idle. Shutdown latency ranges from 0 to 1440 minutes (24 hours). If RunForever is set to True, this property is ignored. ShutdownAfter is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

Set to "Local" to indicate that objects within the application run within a dedicated local server process (server application). Set to "Inproc" to indicate that objects run in their creator's process (library application). Defaults to local
Indicates whether access checks are performed for the application when clients make calls into it.

Enables a server process to continue if an application is idle. If set to True, the server process does not shut down when left idle. If set to False, the process shuts down according to the value set by the ShutdownAfter property. RunForever is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <ComponentServices.Application.AddComponent Path="C:\Soutions\MyNamespace.MyAssembly.dll" ApplicationName="MyApplicationName" Identity="Interactive User" Runtime="1.1" ActivationString="Local" RunForever="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.summary: Performs the action of this task.

member.value: The COM+ Application name. The application will be created if it doesn't exist

member.value: Sets the delay before shutting down a server process after it becomes idle. Shutdown latency ranges from 0 to 1440 minutes (24 hours). If RunForever is set to True, this property is ignored. ShutdownAfter is not enabled for library (in-process) applications.

member.summary: Gets or sets the type of activation for the application.
member.value: "Local" - local activation indicates that objects within the application run within a dedicated local server process (server application). "Inproc" - in-process activation indicates that objects run in their creator's process (library application). Defaults to "Local".

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.GetProperty
member.summary: Installs an MSI package.

remarks.code: <Msi.Install MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to install.
The GUID product code of the product to install.
The path to the log file for the installation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.install.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom installation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide installation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of installation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.
A delimited list of the names of features to be installed. This is not necessary if the MSI does not have features configured, or you wish all features to be installed.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Msi.Install MsiPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.msi" ProductCode="b6b6f41c-fd3e-4b5b-8a73-c59494974990" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.install.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" Features="MSMQ,BTS2004,WebServices" /> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type
member.summary: Login Types

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.Interactive
member.summary: This logon type is intended for users who will be interactively using the computer, such as a user being logged on by a terminal server, remote shell, or similar process. This logon type has the additional expense of caching logon information for disconnected operations; therefore, it is inappropriate for some client/server applications, such as a mail server.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.Network
member.summary: This logon type is intended for high performance servers to authenticate plaintext passwords. The LogonUser function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.Batch
member.summary: This logon type is intended for batch servers, where processes may be executing on behalf of a user without their direct intervention. This type is also for higher performance servers that process many plaintext authentication attempts at a time, such as mail or Web servers. The LogonUser function does not cache credentials for this logon type.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.Service
member.summary: Indicates a service-type logon. The account provided must have the service privilege enabled.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.Unlock
member.summary: This logon type is for GINA DLLs that log on users who will be interactively using the computer. This logon type can generate a unique audit record that shows when the workstation was unlocked.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.NetworkCleartext
member.summary: This logon type preserves the name and password in the authentication package, which allows the server to make connections to other network servers while impersonating the client. A server can accept plaintext credentials from a client, call LogonUser, verify that the user can access the system across the network, and still communicate with other servers. NOTE: Windows NT: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Security.Login.login32Type.NewCredentials
member.summary: This logon type allows the caller to clone its current token and specify new credentials for outbound connections. The new logon session has the same local identifier but uses different credentials for other network connections. NOTE: This logon type is supported only by the LOGON32_PROVIDER_WINNT50 logon provider. NOTE: Windows NT: This value is not supported.

members.member:
Converts a set of Xml files to the canonicalized form, in accordance with the algorithm specified in http://www.w3.org/TR/xml-c14n
<Xml.CanonicalizeFile SourceFiles="sourceFiles" DestinationFiles="destinationFiles" Timeout="timeout" > </Xml.CanonicalizeFile>
where:
sourceFiles (Required)
The full paths to the xml files that are to be transformed to their canonicalized form.
destinationFiles
The full paths to the canonicalized Xml files. These files will be created if they do not already exist. remarks>
<Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Xml.CanonicalizeFile SourceFiles="C:\SourceFiles\file1.xml;C:\TransformedFiles\file2.xml" DestinationFiles="C:\TransformedFiles\file1.xml;C:\TransformedFiles\file2.xml" </Xml.CanonicalizeFile> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Tools.Installshield
member.summary: Builds the specified Installshield project.

remarks.para: where:
The fully qualified path to the folder where you want the output folders and files to be placed.

The path to the .ism file that you would like to build. This path can be fully qualified, relative, or just the file name. If only the project file name is passed, the file is retrieved relative to the current working directory.
The name of the release.

This parameter allows you to specify whether you would like to have your release compressed into one file or remain uncompressed in multiple files. The valid arguments for this parameter are "COMP" and "UNCOMP". To specify that your release be compressed into one file, use the "COMP" argument. If you do not want your release compressed, use the "UNCOMP" argument. This parameter is optional. If the release name already exists, the configuration will be based on what was specified in the IDE. If this is ignored for a new release, the new package will be uncompressed.
A list of directories for which all files within them are to be made writeable for use by InstallShield.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.SourceSafe.LabelGet
member.summary: Increments the version number, labels Visual SourceSafe and does a get against the new label.
member.remarks:
<SourceSafe.LabelGet Database="database" Username="username" Password="password" GetParameter="getParameter" Label="label" OnlyIncremementRevision="onlyIncrementRevision" Project="project" VersionNumber="versionNumber" VersionNumberConfigFileLocation="versionNumberConfigFileLocation" VersionNumberConfigVSSLocation="versionNumberConfigVSSLocation" WorkingDirectory="workingDirectory" > </SourceSafe.LabelGet>
where:
database
The VSS database location. This database must exist and must be a valid VSS database.
username
The username that will be used when labelling VSS
password
The password for the username specified in username
getParameter
Allows a specific version of files/projects to be supplied
label
Label to use when getting a particular version.
onlyIncremementRevision
Force Revision only change. So 2.0.1188.14 would be 2.0.1188.15 on the next automatic label from the source control system.
project
The VSS style syntax for project location.
versionNumber
If specified then $(VersionNumber) is set to this value and replaced as appropriate in the xml config file
versionNumberConfigFileLocation
Fully Qualified file name to the xml config file. The file contains, in Xml format, the major, minor, build and revision number.
For example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <configuration> <appSettings> <add key="major" value="1" /> <add key="minor" value="2" /> <add key="build" value="1354" /> <add key="revision" value="155" /> </appSettings> </configuration>
versionNumberConfigVSSLocation
The path to the config file specified in versionNumberConfigFileLocation inside VSS, using VSS-style notation.
workingDirectory
The full path to the working directory on the local machine for the cod

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Certificates.AddCertificate
member.summary: Imports a certificate (and private key if required) from a pfx or cer file. Note that repeated imports of the same certificate will not result in multiple copies being installed (but todo in this name space: FindCertificates, DeleteCertificate ...)

remarks.para: where:

Name of certificate store in which to place new certificate, defaults to "MY"
Should be one of:-
AddressBook: The X509 certificate store for other users.
AuthRoot: The X509 certificate store for third-party certificate authorities (CAs).
CertificateAuthority: The X509 certificate store for intermediate certificate authorities (CAs).
Disallowed: The X509 certificate store for revoked certificates.
My: The X509 certificate store for personal certificates.
Root: The X509 certificate store for trusted root certificate authorities (CAs).
TrustedPeople: The X509 certificate store for directly trusted people and resources.
TrustedPublisher: The X509 certificate store for directly trusted publishers.
password for the pfx file from which the certificate is to be imported, defaults to blank
set to true if the certificate is to be installed in the machine store, false for the user store, defaults to false
Full path to pfx file for import
outputs the certificate thumbprint. Used to uniquely identify certificate in further tasks.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <AddCertificate FileName="" Password="xyzzy" StorePrivateKey="true" MachineStore="false"> <Output TaskParameter="thumbprint" PropertyName="NewCertHash"/> </AddCertificate> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Vault.GetLatest
member.summary: Performs a GET from the Sourcegear Vault server specified. The latest version is retrieved.

remarks.code: <Vault.GetLatest Server="server" Repository="repository" Username="username" Password="password" DestinationDirectory="destinationPath" ItemPath="itemPath" VaultClientPath="clientExePath" UseSSL="useSSL" />
remarks.para: where:
The IP address or hostname of the Vault server to connect to.
The Vault username.
The password for the username specified in username
The full path to download repository files to.
The full repository path to the item to perform the get operation on.
Optional - the path to vault.exe. If the Vault registry keys exist or the path to vault.exe is set in your enviroment path, this does not need to be used.
Optional (default False) - if set SSL will be used to communicate with the Vault server. If enabled the Vault server specified in server must support SSL.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <Vault.GetLatest Server="192.168.1.100" Repository="MyCode" Username="username" Password="password" DestinationDirectory="c:\ItemSource" ItemPath="$/Repos/Item" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions
member.summary: Sets permissions on the specified MessageQueue.

remarks.para: where:
The message queue that the permissions changes will apply to. The path must be prefixed by the machine name (or "." to represent the local computer). See for more details.
Allows the specified access right to either be granted (if set to "false") or revoked (if set to "true") for the specified user. Defaults to "true".
The individual, group, or computer that is to get additional rights to the queue or have rights to the queue removed.
The specific access right to be granted or revoked for the specified user. See for valid values.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the SetPermissions class.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.InternalExecute
member.summary: Performs the action of this task.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.QueuePath
member.summary: The message queue that the permissions changes will apply to.
member.value: The path must be prefixed by the machine name (or "." to represent the local computer). See for more details.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.DenyPermission
member.summary: Allows the specified access right to either be granted or revoked for the specified user.
member.value: Set to true to revoke the specified access right, or false to grant the specified access right. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.UserName
member.summary: The individual, group, or computer that gets additional rights to the queue or has them revoked (depending on the value of DenyPermission).
member.value: The user can be any valid trustee, which includes individual users, groups of users, or a computer. If the user is an individual, use the format DOMAIN\ user for the user parameter. You can specify "." for the user parameter to indicate the local computer.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.MessageQueue.SetPermissions.AccessRight
member.summary: The access right to grant the specified user on the specified queue. If the DenyPermission property is set to true, this access right will be revoked from the specified user, otherwise it will be granted.
member.value: Can be any of the following: "ChangeQueuePermissions" - The right to modify queue permissions "DeleteJournalMessage" - The right to delete messages from the journal queue "DeleteMessage" - The right to delete messages from the queue "DeleteQueue" - The right to delete the queue "FullControl" - Full rights to the queue. A union of all other rights in the enumeration. "GenericRead" - A combination of GetQueueProperties, GetQueuePermissions, ReceiveMessage, and ReceiveJournalMessage. "GenericWrite" - A combination of GetQueueProperties, GetQueuePermissions, and WriteMessage. "GetQueuePermissions" - The right to read queue permissions. "GetQueueProperties" - The right to read properties of the queue. "PeekMessage" - The right to peek messages from the queue. "ReceiveJournalMessage" - The right to receive messages from the journal queue. This includes the rights to delete and peek messages from the journal queue. "ReceiveMessage" - The right to receive messages from the queue. This includes the rights to delete and peek messages. "SetQueueProperties" - The right to modify properties of the queue "TakeQueueOwnership" - The right to take ownership of the queue. "WriteMessage" - The right to send messages to the queue.

rootFolder = C:\Dev\folderToZip (folder contains file 1.txt, 2.txt and sub folder 'subfolder' with the file 3.txt) ZIP-Archive will contain: 1.txt 2.txt subfolder\3.txt

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.SetAttribute
member.summary: Writes an attribute to every element that matches the specified XPath expression. Will fail if no matches are found for the XPath expression. Unlike SetValue, if the element is found, but the attribute does not already exist the task will not fail. Instead the attribute will be added.

remarks.code: <XmlFile.SetAttribute Path="path" XPath="xpath" Name="name" Value="value" Namespaces="namespaces" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="ignoreNoMatchFailure" Force="force"/>
remarks.para: where:
The path of the XML file to read.
The XPath expression to evaluate for the element(s) on which to set the attribute.
The name of the attribute to set.
The value to assign to the attribute.
Optional TaskItems array detailing each of the namespace declarations required to read/maintain the target document. Each TaskItem should have 2 elements <Prefix> and <Uri>.
If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
If set to true, this will force the file to be updated even if it is Read Only. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <XmlFile.SetAttribute Path="c:\app.config" XPath="/configuration/appSettings/add[@key='myKey']" Name="value" Value="my data value" Namespaces="@(ConfigNamespaces)" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="true" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.summary: Carry out this task's action.

member.summary: Name of the Attribute to update. If not specified the element's value will be updated.

member.summary: The new value to assign to the element or attribute.
member.value: The new value to assign to the element or attribute.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.SetAttribute.IgnoreNoMatchFailure
member.summary: If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
member.value: If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.SetAttribute.Force
member.summary: If set to true, this will modify the xml file even if it is read-only. Defaults to false.
member.value: If set to true, this will modify the xml file even if it is read-only. Defaults to false.

summary.para: Runs Nunit, creates a summary file and returns test statistics.
Testcases must be written according to the Nunit documentation.
For more information and a copy of Nunit please visit http://www.nunit.org

remarks.code: <Tools.Nunit AssemblyName="assemblyname" Version="version" Fixture="fixture" IncludeCategory="includecategory" ExcludeCategory="excludecategory" OutputXmlFileName="outputxmlfilename" OutputXmlTransformFile="outputxmltransformfile"> <Output TaskParameter="Category" ItemName="itemName" /> <Output TaskParameter="Pass" ItemName="itemName" /> <Output TaskParameter="Fail" ItemName="itemName" /> <Output TaskParameter="TimeTaken" ItemName="itemName" /> </Tools.Nunit>
remarks.para: where:
Version of Nunit to run
Fully qualified fixture name if required
List of test Categories to run ';' separated
List of test Categories to ignore ';' separated
File name to write the results to
File name of transform file if required

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Tools.Nunit AssemblyName="MyTestAssembly.dll" Version="2.2" Fixture="" IncludeCategory="bvt" ExcludeCategory="stress" OutputXmlFileName="MyTestAssemblyResults.xml"> <Output TaskParameter="Pass" ItemName="TestPass"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="Fail" ItemName="TestFail"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="NotRun" ItemName="TestNoRun"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="Total" ItemName="TestTotal"></Output> <Output TaskParameter="TimeTaken" ItemName="TestTimeTaken"></Output> </Tools.Nunit> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.File.Replace
member.summary:
Reads in a text file and modifies the contents by searching for and replacing a text string or text satisfying a regular expression pattern.
Supports unicode files and case-insensitive searches.

remarks.code: <File.Replace Path="path" Force="force" NewValue="newValue" TextEncoding="textEncoding" RegularExpression="regularExpression" OldValue="oldValue" IgnoreCase="ignoreCase" > </File.Replace>
remarks.para: where:
The full path and filename of the text file to be modified.
If set to true, this will modify the text file even if it is read-only. Set to false to ignore read-only files. Defaults to false.
The new value for the specified text to search for.
The regular expression pattern to match.
The text string to search for.
Default behaviour is to auto detect the encoding. Specify a valid encoding to force a particular encoding.
If set to true, search will be case-insensitive. Set to false for case-sensitive searches. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <!-- Replaces all instances of the text string "Test" in file1.txt with the text string "MODIFIED". --> <Target Name="Test" > <File.Replace Path="C:\SourceFiles\file1.txt" OldValue="Test" NewValue="MODIFIED" /> </Target> <!-- Replaces runs of white space in file2.txt with a comma and a blank. --> <Target Name="TestWithRegularExpression" > <File.Replace Path="C:\SourceFiles\file2.txt" RegularExpression="\s+" NewValue=", " /> </Target> </Project>

member.summary: Performs the action of this task.

member.param: The search text.
The old value.

member.returns: Replaced string content

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.XmlFile.SetValue
member.summary: Writes the specified value to the element(s) or attribute(s) that match the passed XPath expression. Will fail if no match found for the XPath expression.

remarks.para: where:
The path of the XML file to read.
The XPath expression to evaluate for the element(s) or attribute(s) whose value to set.
The value to assign.
Optional TaskItems array detailing each of the namespace declarations required to read/maintain the target document. Each TaskItem should have 2 elements <Prefix> and <Uri>.
If set to true, no Exception will be thrown if no matches made for the supplied XPath. Defaults to false.
If set to true, this will force the file to be updated even if it is Read Only. Defaults to false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <XmlFile.SetValue Path="c:\app.config" XPath="/configuration/appSettings/add[@key='myKey']/@value" Value="my data value" Namespaces="@(ConfigNamespaces)" IgnoreNoMatchFailure="true" Force="true" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Wix.LinkMsi
member.summary: Links intermediate *.wixobj files to build a complete MSI. The task can be used to create the intermediate files that this task expects as input.

remarks.para: About Wix: Wix was originally a Microsoft tool that has been released into the open source community under the Common Public License. The binaries and source code can be downloaded from SourceForge.
remarks.code: <LinkMsi SourceFiles="sourceFiles" OutputFile="outputFile" WixPath="wixPath" BasePath="basePath" InformationLevel="informationLevel" WarningLevel="warningLevel" TreatWarningsAsErrors="treatWarningsAsErrors" KeepTemporaryFiles="keepTemporaryFiles" />
remarks.para: where:
A delimited list of the source files to generate the MSI from. These should have the extension *.wixobj.
The path to the MSI to produce. This should have the extension *.msi.
The path to the directory that the Wix executables reside in.
The base path used to locate all files if they are provided as a relative path. The default is the current directory.
An integer between zero (verbose information) and three (no information). The default is zero.
An integer between zero (all warnings) and three (no warnings). The default is zero.
true if warnings are treated as errors, or false otherwise. The default is false.
true if temporary files should be kept, or false otherwise. Keeping the temporary files can be useful for debugging purposes. The default is false.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <LinkMsi SourceFiles="IntermediateFile1.wixobj;IntermediateFile2.wixobj" OutputFile="MyPackage.msi" WixPath="C:\Program Files\Wix" BasePath="C:\Build\Msi\ObjectFiles" InformationLevel="1" WarningLevel="2" TreatWarningsAsErrors="true" KeepTemporaryFiles="false" /> </Target> </Project>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Wix.LinkMsi.InternalExecute
member.summary: Executes the task.

member.value: The base path used to locate all files if they are provided as a relative path.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Msi.Install
member.summary: Installs an MSI package.

remarks.code: <Msi.Install MsiPath="msiPath" ProductCode="productCode" LogFile="logFile" LogOptions="logOptions" UserInterfaceLevel="userInterfaceLevel" LoadUserProfile="loadUserProfile" PropertyFiles="propertyFiles" Properties="properties" Features="features" />
remarks.para: where:
The path to the MSI to install.
The GUID product code of the product to install.
The path to the log file for the installation. The recommended file name is the name of the MSI with the extension *.install.log.

A delimited list of logging options. Possible values are: Default, StatusMessages, Warnings, Errors, ActionStart, ActionSpecificRequests, UserRequests, InitialParameters, OutOfMemory, TerminalProperties, Verbose, AppendLog, FlushEachLine, AllInformation. The default is Default. Please see the documentation for further information.

The user interface level displayed by MsiExec during the installation. Possible values are: None, Basic, ReducedWithModalDialog, FullWithModalDialog, NoneWithModalDialog, BasicWithModalDialog, BasicWithNoModalDialogs. The default is None. Please see the documentation for further information.

true if the user's profile is loaded during the processing of the MSI, or false otherwise. This may be needed for some custom installation actions such as configuring ports and channels in Microsoft BizTalk Server. The default is false.

A delimited list of XML property files that provide installation properties for the MSI. Multiple property files are allowed so that you can have a hierarchy - the first file provides a base set of properties (e.g. environmental properties for a particular rig) and subsequent files can override these to provide a more specific property or add new properties (e.g. properties for a machine, then properties for an individual MSI).

A delimited list of installation properties in the format Name=Value. If any property files have been specified, then the properties specified here are seen as the most significant and can overwrite any of the property values specified in the files.
A delimited list of the names of features to be installed. This is not necessary if the MSI does not have features configured, or you wish all features to be installed.

* - Either msiPath or productCode must be provided. If both are provided then msiPath takes precedence and productCode is ignored. If neither are provided then the task will throw an exception when it executes.

member.example:
<Project> <Target Name="Test"> <Msi.Install MsiPath="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.msi" ProductCode="b6b6f41c-fd3e-4b5b-8a73-c59494974990" LogFile="C:\Build\Msi\Packages\MyPackage.install.log" LogOptions="Default;Verbose" UserInterfaceLevel="None" LoadUserProfile="true" PropertyFiles="C:\Build\Properties\Global.xml;C:\Build\Properties\Rig4.xml" Properties="INSTALLDIR=C:\Install;DOMAIN=rig4;MACHINE=r4app01" Features="MSMQ,BTS2004,WebServices" /> </Target> </Project>
A sample property file is shown below. Note that you must include the namespace for the file to be parsed correctly.
<Properties xmlns="urn:sdc-microsoft-com:deployment:properties:v2.0"> <Property Name="MY_PROPERTY" Value="some value" /> <Property Name="ANOTHER_PROPERTY" Value="some other value" /> <Property Name="SOMETHING_ELSE" Value="hello world" /> ... etc ... </Properties>

member.name: M:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.SqlServer.ScriptExecutor.Execute(Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.Configuration.SqlServer.ScriptExecutionInfo)
member.summary: Executes a SQL script.
member.param: Information about the script or scripts to be executed.

remarks.para: The input will be validated before the script is executed. If an incorrect combination of input has been supplied, an ApplicationException is raised. Valid inputs are defined below.
ServerName - mandatory if ConnectionString is not specified.
DatabaseName - mandatory if ConnectionString is not specified.
ConnectionString - mandatory if ServerName and DatabaseName are not specified.
CommandTimeout - optional and will default to 30 seconds if not specified.
Path - mandatory if Sql is not specified.
Sql - mandatory if Path is not specified.
SubstitutionParameters - optional.
Exclusions - only valid if Path is specified, wildcard characters are not supported for exclusions.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CheckComponentInstalled
member.summary: Check that a windows component is installed such as IIS

remarks.code: <CheckComponentInstalled Ids="ids" IdComparisonOperators="idsComparisonOperators" UnaryOperators="unaryOperators" InstalledComponentsXml="installedComponentsXml"> <Output TaskParameter="Summary" ItemName="SummaryItem" /> <Output TaskParameter="Success" ItemName="SuccessItem" /> </CheckComponentInstalled>
remarks.para: where:
Ids of the components to check for as found in: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Setup\OC Manager\Subcomponents For example, "iis_www"
Name comparison operators for each of the component ids speciifed in ids. Can be any of: "Equals", "Contains" "LessThan" "GreaterThan" "LessThanOrEquals" "GreaterThanOrEquals"
Unary operators for the respective idsComparisonOperators, allowing (for example) "Not Equals" to be created. Can be "None" or "Not".
A list of the components installed on the local machine. This will typically be generated by the GetInstalledComponents task

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test" > <CheckComponentInstalled Ids="aspnet" IdComparisonOperators="Equals" UnaryOperators="None", InstalledComponentsXml="$(InstalledComponentsXmlItem)"> <Output TaskParameter="Summary" ItemName="SummaryItem" /> <Output TaskParameter="Success" ItemName="SuccessItem" /> </CheckComponentInstalled> </Target> </Project>

members.member:
Adds a metadata item containing a sequence number to each item in the itemlist passed.
<CreateSequenceMetadata ItemList="itemList" MetadataName="metadataName" FormatString="formatString" [Start="startNumber"] [Increment="incrementNumber"] > <Output TaskParameter="ItemList" ItemName="outputList" /> </CreateSequenceMetadata>
where:
ItemList (Required)
The itemlist that the metadata is to be added to. This is also the output itemlist.
MetadataName (Required)
The name of the metadata to be created for each item.
FormatString (Required)
A format string for the sequence number. This is a String.Format() type format string and should include the {0} placeholder for the sequence number.
Start (optional)
An optional numeric value to start the sequence number at. This defaults to 1 if not specified.
Increment (Optional)
An optional numeric value used to increment the sequence number by. This defaults to 1 if not specified.
This example will output an itemlist called IndexedNames based on the Names itemlist with an additional metadata item called Index. Each value in Index will be a unique sequential number of three digits with leading zeroes.
<Project> <Target Name="Test" > <CreateSequenceMetadata MetadataItem="Index" FormatString="{0:000}" ItemList="@(Names)"> <Output TaskParameter="ItemList" ItemName="IndexedNames" /> </CreateSequenceMetadata> </Target> </Project>
/// The second example is similar to the previous one but demonstrates how the FormatString parameter may be used to create string values that are more than just a sequence number. Also, Start and Increment values are used to set values other than 1 for these parameters. The metadata values created will be NAME1000, NAME1010, etc.
<Project> <Target Name="Test" > <CreateSequenceMetadata MetadataItem="Index" FormatString="NAME{0:0000}" ItemList="@(Names)" Start="1000" Increment="10"> <Output TaskParameter="ItemList" ItemName="IndexedNames" /> </CreateSequenceMetadata> </Target> </Project>

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSequenceMetadata.FormatString
member.summary: A format string for the sequence number. This is a String.Format() type format string and should include the {0} placeholder for the sequence number.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSequenceMetadata.MetadataName
member.summary: The name of the metadata to be created for each item.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSequenceMetadata.Start
member.summary: An optional numeric value to start the sequence number at. This defaults to 1 if not specified.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSequenceMetadata.Increment
member.summary: An optional numeric value used to increment the sequence number by. This defaults to 1 if not specified.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Sdc.Tasks.CreateSequenceMetadata.ItemList
member.summary: The itemlist that the metadata is to be added to. This is also the output itemlist.

The name of the log the source's entries are written to. Possible values include: Application, Security, System, or a custom event log.

example.code: <Project> <Target Name="Test"> <EventSource.Exists Source="MyEventSource" LogName="Application"> <Output TaskParameter="DoesExist" PropertyName="MyEventSourceExists" /> </EventSource.Exists> <EventSource.Create Condition="'$(MyEventSourceExists)' == 'false'" Source="MyEventSource" LogName="Application" /> </Target> </Project>
